intro: Kochia excavata, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the western United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant has a succulent appearance, with thick, fleshy leaves that help it conserve water in harsh environments. Kochia excavata produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in dense, spiky inflorescences. It is often found in sandy soils and is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low precipitation.
